qas.question: How far back does Egypt's history date back?
Why is Egypt considered a cradle of civilisation?

answers.text: earliest developments of writing, agriculture, urbanisation, organised religion and central government

qas.question: What were some of Egypt's foreign influences?

answers.text: Greek, Persian, Roman, Arab, Ottoman, and European

qas.question: What are iconic monumuents of Egypt?

answers.text: Giza Necropolis and its Great Sphinx

qas.question: In what century were islamic conquests of Egypt?

context: Egypt has one of the longest histories of any modern country, arising in the <a0_0>tenth millennium BC<a0_0/> as one of the world's first nation states. Considered a cradle of civilisation, Ancient Egypt experienced some of the <a1_0>earliest developments of writing, agriculture, urbanisation, organised religion and central government<a1_0/>. Iconic monuments such as the <a3_0>Giza Necropolis and its Great Sphinx<a3_0/>, as well the ruins of Memphis, Thebes, Karnak, and the Valley of the Kings, reflect this legacy and remain a significant focus of archaeological study and popular interest worldwide. Egypt's rich cultural heritage is an integral part of its national identity, having endured, and at times assimilated, various foreign influences, including <a2_0>Greek, Persian, Roman, Arab, Ottoman, and European<a2_0/>. Although Christianised in the first century of the Common Era, it was subsequently Islamised due to the Islamic conquests of the <a4_0>seventh century<a4_0/>.
